extent.charseq: WASHINGTON Sen. John McCain, who pushed the White House to support a ban on torture, suggested Sunday that harsh treatment of a terrorism suspect who knew of an imminent attack would not violate international standards.

WASHINGTON — Sen. John McCain, who pushed the White House to support a ban on torture, suggested Sunday that harsh treatment of a terrorism suspect who knew of an imminent attack would not violate international standards.
the US army that broke the story and made it public
liberal spin that made it out to be our military
the Supreme Court s shattering 2004 Rasul decision,
the federal courts, thanks to the Supreme Court s shattering 2004 Rasul decision,
politicians who have to run for reelection in specific districts
a time bomb within Senator McCain s proposal
a suitcase nuke that soon will explode
a decent and impressive public servant

who already struggle to stay one step ahead of people dedicated to slaughtering our countrymen by the thousands as they did just over four years ago at home and continue to do nearly every day in Iraq
Al Qaeda, which shouldn t even get Geneva Convention protections,
Mohamed Al-`Owhali, who had blown up the U.S. embassy in Nairobi, killing over 200 innocent people
a Saudi in the custody of Kenya whose only connection to the U.S. was to bomb our embassy
the judge reconsidered and permitted the confession to be introduced at the trial (at which al-`Owhali was convicted)
Kenya, which does not provide Miranda protections
the FBI agents who were allowed to question him
enemy combatants to their wartime detention
our enemies with the fundamental rights of Americans
All Veterans that also embrace "torture" as an American value and/or ideal, please raise your hands?!!!!!!!
